title: Starbucks warns of profit-growth miss as stock’s rapid rise prompts ‘pull forward’ of buybacks
text:
Shares of Starbucks slumped Wednesday after executives warned that 2020 profit growth will be below its target, citing a “pull forward” of about $2 billion in stock repurchases, which were earmarked to help boost next year’s per-share results.

Starbucks Corp. shares SBUX, -1.76% fell 0.7% to close at $96.11, paring earlier losses of as much as 3.9%. Trading volume topped 12.9 million shares, well above the full-day average of about 7.3 million shares, FactSet data show.

The coffee seller said it expects fiscal 2020 earnings-per-share growth to be below its long-term growth target of “at least 10%.” The current FactSet consensus for fiscal 2020 EPS of $3.12 implies 10.6% growth over the fiscal 2019 consensus of $2.82.

At a Starbucks investor gathering in December, Chief Financial Officer Patrick Grismer said that, as a result of the benefit of share repurchases and efforts to cut general and administrative expenses, he expected EPS growth of “at least 13%” on average for 2020 and 2021.

On Wednesday, at the Goldman Sachs Global Retailing Conference, Grismer said one “very significant headwind” to 2020 EPS growth is the effective tax rate, given the one-time nature of the tax benefit realized in 2019.

Regarding share repurchases, Grismer said the company chose to pull forward about $2 billion in share repurchases that were originally planned next year to the current fiscal year.

“So in the context of a rapidly appreciating share price and given that we have the liquidity to do it, we pulled forward those share repurchases, and we’re able to preserve what we had expected by way of an EPS growth contribution to or from the share repurchases, net of the associated interest expense,” Grismer said at the Goldman conference, according to a FactSet transcript. “But again we do expect and EPS growth outlook for fiscal 2020 that is meaningfully below the ongoing algorithm that we had laid out at our investor day.”

The reason the stock-price appreciation warranted increased share buybacks was that at the investor gathering in December, Grismer said the EPS growth model included an algorithm that supports an EPS benefit from share repurchases of about 2%. If the stock-price appreciation is more rapid than expected, the amount of shares the company can repurchase decreases, which also decreases the benefit to per-share earnings.

Starbucks shares had run up 47% during the first three quarters of fiscal 2019, including a 12.8% rise in the third fiscal quarter, which ended in June, a 15.4% jump in the second quarter and a 13.3% gain in the first quarter.

Since the end of the third quarter, the stock has risen another 14.7%. It closed at a record $99.11 on July 26.

In comparison, the SPDR Consumer Discretionary Select Sector exchange-traded fund XLY, -2.04% has gained 0.9% since the end of June and the S&P 500 index SPX, -1.94% has lost 4.0%.

Including a $2 billion accelerated-share-repurchase agreement effective in March, Starbucks said in its most recent quarterly filing that it had spent $8 billion to buy back 116.1 million shares during the first three quarters of fiscal 2019. That represented about 9.4% of the shares outstanding as of the end of fiscal 2018.

As of June 30, about 52.7 million shares remained available for repurchase under the current buyback program.

Bernstein analyst Sara Senatore said she didn’t believe investors weren’t too surprised by the lowered guidance, given that tax benefits and share-repurchase plans were telegraphed.

“The timing of the update is a bit puzzling given the company reported [third-quarter] results less than six weeks ago and did not update guidance then, though the decision to provide explicit guidance may reflect consensus’s failure to model accordingly,” Senatore wrote in a note to clients.

Grismer stressed that despite the lowered EPS-growth outlook, Starbucks was “firing on all cylinders” from an operating-performance perspective. He affirmed the revenue-growth guidance range of 7% to 9% for 2020, while the FactSet revenue consensus for 2020 of $28.42 billion implies 7.6% growth over the 2019 consensus of $26.42 billion.

“All in, while there doesn’t appear to be any change in [Starbucks’s] broader fundamental outlook …, these adjustments are a reminder that the [Starbucks] story is complicated and that growth is not always poised to proceed in a linear fashion,” analyst Bonnie Herzog at Wells Fargo wrote in a note to clients.
